00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
How many Creationists do we have in the room?

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
Probably none. I think we're all Darwinians.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:24.958
And yet many Darwinians are anxious, a little uneasy --

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:29.958
would like to see some limits on just how far the Darwinism goes.

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
It's all right.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:35.958
You know spiderwebs? Sure, they are products of evolution.

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:39.958
The World Wide Web? Not so sure.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
Beaver dams, yes. Hoover Dam, no.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:47.958
What do they think it is that prevents the products of human ingenuity

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
from being themselves, fruits of the tree of life,

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:55.958
and hence, in some sense, obeying evolutionary rules?

00:00:56.958 --> 00:01:00.958
And yet people are interestingly resistant

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:07.958
to the idea of applying evolutionary thinking to thinking -- to our thinking.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:11.958
And so I'm going to talk a little bit about that,

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:15.958
keeping in mind that we have a lot on the program here.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:19.958
So you're out in the woods, or you're out in the pasture,

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.958
and you see this ant crawling up this blade of grass.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
It climbs up to the top, and it falls,

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:28.958
and it climbs, and it falls, and it climbs --

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:32.958
trying to stay at the very top of the blade of grass.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:37.958
What is this ant doing? What is this in aid of?

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:44.958
What goals is this ant trying to achieve by climbing this blade of grass?

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
What's in it for the ant?

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:52.958
And the answer is: nothing. There's nothing in it for the ant.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
Well then, why is it doing this?

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:57.958
Is it just a fluke?

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:04.958
Yeah, it's just a fluke. It's a lancet fluke.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
It's a little brain worm.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:11.958
It's a parasitic brain worm that has to get into the stomach of a sheep or a cow

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
in order to continue its life cycle.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:19.958
Salmon swim upstream to get to their spawning grounds,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:23.958
and lancet flukes commandeer a passing ant,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:28.958
crawl into its brain, and drive it up a blade of grass like an all-terrain vehicle.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:32.958
So there's nothing in it for the ant.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:40.958
The ant's brain has been hijacked by a parasite that infects the brain,

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
inducing suicidal behavior.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
Pretty scary.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:50.958
Well, does anything like that happen with human beings?

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:56.958
This is all on behalf of a cause other than one's own genetic fitness, of course.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:03:01.958
Well, it may already have occurred to you

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:11.958
that Islam means "surrender," or "submission of self-interest to the will of Allah."

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:17.958
Well, it's ideas -- not worms -- that hijack our brains.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:22.958
Now, am I saying that a sizable minority of the world's population

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:28.958
has had their brain hijacked by parasitic ideas?

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
No, it's worse than that.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:35.958
Most people have.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
(Laughter)

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
There are a lot of ideas to die for.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
Freedom, if you're from New Hampshire.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
(Laughter)

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:52.958
Justice. Truth. Communism.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
Many people have laid down their lives for communism,

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:58.958
and many have laid down their lives for capitalism.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:02.958
And many for Catholicism. And many for Islam.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:07.958
These are just a few of the ideas that are to die for.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
They're infectious.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:14.958
Yesterday, Amory Lovins spoke about "infectious repititis."

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
It was a term of abuse, in effect.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
This is unthinking engineering.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:23.958
Well, most of the cultural spread that goes on

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:27.958
is not brilliant, new, out-of-the-box thinking.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
It's "infectious repetitis,"

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:34.958
and we might as well try to have a theory of what's going on when that happens

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.958
so that we can understand the conditions of infection.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:47.958
Hosts work hard to spread these ideas to others.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:53.958
I myself am a philosopher, and one of our occupational hazards

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:57.958
is that people ask us what the meaning of life is.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
And you have to have a bumper sticker,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
you know. You have to have a statement.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
So, this is mine.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:09.958
The secret of happiness is: Find something more important than you are

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
and dedicate your life to it.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:15.958
Most of us -- now that the "Me Decade" is well in the past --

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
now we actually do this.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
One set of ideas or another

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
have simply replaced our biological imperatives in our own lives.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
This is what our summum bonum is.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
It's not maximizing the number of grandchildren we have.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.958
Now, this is a profound biological effect.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
It's the subordination of genetic interest to other interests.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:41.958
And no other species does anything at all like it.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
Well, how are we going to think about this?

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:47.958
It is, on the one hand, a biological effect, and a very large one.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
Unmistakable.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
Now, what theories do we want to use to look at this?

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
Well, many theories. But how could something tie them together?

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
The idea of replicating ideas;

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:03.958
ideas that replicate by passing from brain to brain.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:08.958
Richard Dawkins, whom you'll be hearing later in the day, invented the term "memes,"

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:13.958
and put forward the first really clear and vivid version of this idea

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
in his book "The Selfish Gene."

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
Now here am I talking about his idea.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:24.958
Well, you see, it's not his. Yes -- he started it.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
But it's everybody's idea now.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:31.958
And he's not responsible for what I say about memes.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:35.958
I'm responsible for what I say about memes.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
Actually, I think we're all responsible

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:45.958
for not just the intended effects of our ideas,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
but for their likely misuses.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:53.958
So it is important, I think, to Richard, and to me,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:57.958
that these ideas not be abused and misused.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
They're very easy to misuse. That's why they're dangerous.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
And it's just about a full-time job

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
trying to prevent people who are scared of these ideas

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:14.958
from caricaturing them and then running off to one dire purpose or another.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
So we have to keep plugging away,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
trying to correct the misapprehensions

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:27.958
so that only the benign and useful variants of our ideas continue to spread.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
But it is a problem.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:36.958
We don't have much time, and I'm going to go over just a little bit of this and cut out,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
because there's a lot of other things that are going to be said.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:44.958
So let me just point out: memes are like viruses.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
That's what Richard said, back in '93.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
And you might think, "Well, how can that be?

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:55.958
I mean, a virus is -- you know, it's stuff! What's a meme made of?"

00:07:55.958 --> 00:08:00.958
Yesterday, Negroponte was talking about viral telecommunications

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:01.958
but -- what's a virus?

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:05.958
A virus is a string of nucleic acid with attitude.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:06.958
(Laughter)

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
That is, there is something about it

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958
that tends to make it replicate better than the competition does.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:16.958
And that's what a meme is. It's an information packet with attitude.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:22.958
What's a meme made of? What are bits made of, Mom?

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Not silicon.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
They're made of information, and can be carried in any physical medium.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
What's a word made of?

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:35.958
Sometimes when people say, "Do memes exist?"

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:39.958
I say, "Well, do words exist? Are they in your ontology?"

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:44.958
If they are, words are memes that can be pronounced.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
Then there's all the other memes that can't be pronounced.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
There are different species of memes.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:59.958
Remember the Shakers? Gift to be simple?

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
Simple, beautiful furniture?

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
And, of course, they're basically extinct now.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:11.958
And one of the reasons is that among the creed of Shaker-dom

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
is that one should be celibate.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
Not just the priests. Everybody.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:23.958
Well, it's not so surprising that they've gone extinct. (Laughter)

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
But in fact that's not why they went extinct.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
They survived as long as they did

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
at a time when the social safety nets weren't there.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
And there were lots of widows and orphans,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
people like that, who needed a foster home.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
And so they had a ready supply of converts.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
And they could keep it going.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
And, in principle, it could've gone on forever,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
with perfect celibacy on the part of the hosts.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:54.958
The idea being passed on through proselytizing,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
instead of through the gene line.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:03.958
So the ideas can live on in spite of the fact

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
that they're not being passed on genetically.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:10.958
A meme can flourish in spite of having a negative impact on genetic fitness.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:18.958
After all, the meme for Shaker-dom was essentially a sterilizing parasite.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:25.958
There are other parasites that do this -- which render the host sterile.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
It's part of their plan.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
They don't have to have minds to have a plan.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:38.958
I'm just going to draw your attention to just one

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:46.958
of the many implications of the memetic perspective, which I recommend.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
I've not time to go into more of it.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:53.958
In Jared Diamond's wonderful book, "Guns, Germs and Steel,"

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:59.958
he talks about how it was germs, more than guns and steel,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:04.958
that conquered the new hemisphere -- the Western hemisphere --

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
that conquered the rest of the world.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:13.958
When European explorers and travelers spread out,

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
they brought with them the germs

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
that they had become essentially immune to,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
that they had learned how to tolerate over

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
hundreds and hundreds of years, thousands of years,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:28.958
of living with domesticated animals who were the sources of those pathogens.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:34.958
And they just wiped out -- these pathogens just wiped out the native people,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
who had no immunity to them at all.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
And we're doing it again.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:45.958
We're doing it this time with toxic ideas.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:50.958
Yesterday, a number of people -- Nicholas Negroponte and others --

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
spoke about all the wonderful things

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
that are happening when our ideas get spread out,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
thanks to all the new technology all over the world.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:03.958
And I agree. It is largely wonderful. Largely wonderful.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:11.958
But among all those ideas that inevitably flow out into the whole world

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:16.958
thanks to our technology, are a lot of toxic ideas.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:19.958
Now, this has been realized for some time.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:25.958
Sayyid Qutb is one of the founding fathers of fanatical Islam,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:30.958
one of the ideologues that inspired Osama bin Laden.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:35.958
"One has only to glance at its press films, fashion shows, beauty contests,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:41.958
ballrooms, wine bars and broadcasting stations." Memes.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:45.958
These memes are spreading around the world

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:50.958
and they are wiping out whole cultures.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
They are wiping out languages.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:57.958
They are wiping out traditions and practices.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:05.958
And it's not our fault, anymore than it's our fault when our germs lay waste

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
to people that haven't developed the immunity.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:14.958
We have an immunity to all of the junk that lies around the edges of our culture.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:20.958
We're a free society, so we let pornography and all these things -- we shrug them off.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
They're like a mild cold.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
They're not a big deal for us.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
But we should recognize that for many people in the world,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:32.958
they are a big deal.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
And we should be very alert to this.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
As we spread our education and our technology,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:46.958
one of the things that we are doing is we're the vectors of memes

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:52.958
that are correctly viewed by the hosts of many other memes

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
as a dire threat to their favorite memes --

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
the memes that they are prepared to die for.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:02.958
Well now, how are we going to tell the good memes from the bad memes?

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:07.958
That is not the job of the science of memetics.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:13.958
Memetics is morally neutral. And so it should be.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.958
This is not the place for hate and anger.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:22.958
If you've had a friend who's died of AIDS, then you hate HIV.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:26.958
But the way to deal with that is to do science,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:33.958
and understand how it spreads and why in a morally neutral perspective.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
Get the facts.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:39.958
Work out the implications.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:43.958
There's plenty of room for moral passion once we've got the facts

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
and can figure out the best thing to do.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:50.958
And, as with germs, the trick is not to try to annihilate them.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
You will never annihilate the germs.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:59.958
What you can do, however, is foster public health measures and the like

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:04.958
that will encourage the evolution of avirulence.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:12.958
That will encourage the spread of relatively benign mutations

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
of the most toxic varieties.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
That's all the time I have,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
so thank you very much for your attention.

title: The potential of regenerative medicine
transcript: I'm going to talk to you today about hopefully converting fear into hope. When we go to the physician today — when we go to the doctor's office and we walk in, there are words that we just don't want to hear. There are words that we're truly afraid of. Diabetes, cancer, Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, heart failure, lung failure — things that we know are debilitating diseases, for which there's relatively little that can be done.And what I want to lay out for you today is a different way of thinking about how to treat debilitating disease, why it's important, why without it perhaps our health care system will melt down if you think it already hasn't, and where we are clinically today, and where we might go tomorrow, and what some of the hurdles are. And we're going to do all of that in 18 minutes, I promise.I want to start with this slide, because this slide sort of tells the story the way Science Magazine thinks of it. This was an issue from 2002 that they published with a lot of different articles on the bionic human. It was basically a regenerative medicine issue. Regenerative medicine is an extraordinarily simple concept that everybody can understand. It's simply accelerating the pace at which the body heals itself to a clinically relevant timescale. So we know how to do this in many of the ways that are up there. We know that if we have a damaged hip, you can put an artificial hip in. And this is the idea that Science Magazine used on their front cover.This is the complete antithesis of regenerative medicine. This is not regenerative medicine. Regenerative medicine is what Business Week put up when they did a story about regenerative medicine not too long ago. The idea is that instead of figuring out how to ameliorate symptoms with devices and drugs and the like — and I'll come back to that theme a few times — instead of doing that, we will regenerate lost function of the body by regenerating the function of organs and damaged tissue. So that at the end of the treatment, you are the same as you were at the beginning of the treatment.Very few good ideas — if you agree that this is a good idea — very few good ideas are truly novel. And this is just the same. If you look back in history, Charles Lindbergh, who was better known for flying airplanes, was actually one of the first people along with Alexis Carrel, one of the Nobel Laureates from Rockefeller, to begin to think about, could you culture organs? And they published this book in 1937, where they actually began to think about, what could you do in bio-reactors to grow whole organs? We've come a long way since then. I'm going to share with you some of the exciting work that's going on.But before doing that, what I'd like to do is share my depression about the health care system and the need for this with you. Many of the talks yesterday talked about improving the quality of life, and reducing poverty, and essentially increasing life expectancy all around the globe. One of the challenges is that the richer we are, the longer we live. And the longer we live, the more expensive it is to take care of our diseases as we get older.This is simply the wealth of a country versus the percent of population over the age of 65. And you can basically see that the richer a country is, the older the people are within it. Why is this important? And why is this a particularly dramatic challenge right now? If the average age of your population is 30, then the average kind of disease that you have to treat is maybe a broken ankle every now and again, maybe a little bit of asthma. If the average age in your country is 45 to 55, now the average person is looking at diabetes, early-onset diabetes, heart failure, coronary artery disease — things that are inherently more difficult to treat, and much more expensive to treat.Just have a look at the demographics in the U.S. here. This is from "The Untied States of America." In 1930, there were 41 workers per retiree. 41 people who were basically outside of being really sick, paying for the one retiree who was experiencing debilitating disease. In 2010, two workers per retiree in the U.S. And this is matched in every industrialized, wealthy country in the world. How can you actually afford to treat patients when the reality of getting old looks like this?This is age versus cost of health care. And you can see that right around age 45, 40 to 45, there's a sudden spike in the cost of health care. It's actually quite interesting. If you do the right studies, you can look at how much you as an individual spend on your own health care, plotted over your lifetime. And about seven years before you're about to die, there's a spike. And you can actually — (Laughter) — we won't get into that. (Laughter)There are very few things, very few things that you can really do that will change the way that you can treat these kinds of diseases and experience what I would call healthy aging. I'd suggest there are four things, and none of these things include an insurance system or a legal system. All those things do is change who pays. They don't actually change what the actual cost of the treatment is.One thing you can do is not treat. You can ration health care. We won't talk about that anymore. It's too depressing. You can prevent. Obviously a lot of monies should be put into prevention.But perhaps most interesting, to me anyway, and most important, is the idea of diagnosing a disease much earlier on in the progression, and then treating the disease to cure the disease instead of treating a symptom. Think of it in terms of diabetes, for instance. Today, with diabetes, what do we do? We diagnose the disease eventually, once it becomes symptomatic, and then we treat the symptom for 10, 20, 30, 40 years. And we do OK. Insulin's a pretty good therapy. But eventually it stops working, and diabetes leads to a predictable onset of debilitating disease.Why couldn't we just inject the pancreas with something to regenerate the pancreas early on in the disease, perhaps even before it was symptomatic? And it might be a little bit expensive at the time that we did it, but if it worked, we would truly be able to do something different.This video, I think, gets across the concept that I'm talking about quite dramatically. This is a newt re-growing its limb. If a newt can do this kind of thing, why can't we? I'll actually show you some more important features about limb regeneration in a moment. But what we're talking about in regenerative medicine is doing this in every organ system of the body, for tissues and for organs themselves. So today's reality is that if we get sick, the message is we will treat your symptoms, and you need to adjust to a new way of life.I would pose to you that tomorrow — and when tomorrow is we could debate, but it's within the foreseeable future — we will talk about regenerative rehabilitation. There's a limb prosthetic up here, similar actually one on the soldier that's come back from Iraq. There are 370 soldiers that have come back from Iraq that have lost limbs. Imagine if instead of facing that, they could actually face the regeneration of that limb. It's a wild concept. I'll show you where we are at the moment in working towards that concept.But it's applicable, again, to every organ system. How can we do that? The way to do that is to develop a conversation with the body. We need to learn to speak the body's language. And to switch on processes that we knew how to do when we were a fetus. A mammalian fetus, if it loses a limb during the first trimester of pregnancy, will re-grow that limb. So our DNA has the capacity to do these kinds of wound-healing mechanisms. It's a natural process, but it is lost as we age. In a child, before the age of about six months, if they lose their fingertip in an accident, they'll re-grow their fingertip. By the time they're five, they won't be able to do that anymore.So to engage in that conversation with the body, we need to speak the body's language. And there are certain tools in our toolbox that allow us to do this today. I'm going to give you an example of three of these tools through which to converse with the body.The first is cellular therapies. Clearly, we heal ourselves in a natural process, using cells to do most of the work. Therefore, if we can find the right cells and implant them in the body, they may do the healing. Secondly, we can use materials. We heard yesterday about the importance of new materials. If we can invent materials, design materials, or extract materials from a natural environment, then we might be able to have those materials induce the body to heal itself. And finally, we may be able to use smart devices that will offload the work of the body and allow it to heal.I'm going to show you an example of each of these, and I'm going to start with materials. Steve Badylak — who's at the University of Pittsburgh — about a decade ago had a remarkable idea. And that idea was that the small intestine of a pig, if you threw away all the cells, and if you did that in a way that allowed it to remain biologically active, may contain all of the necessary factors and signals that would signal the body to heal itself. And he asked a very important question. He asked the question, if I take that material, which is a natural material that usually induces healing in the small intestine, and I place it somewhere else on a person's body, would it give a tissue-specific response, or would it make small intestine if I tried to make a new ear?I wouldn't be telling you this story if it weren't compelling. The picture I'm about to show you is a compelling picture. (Laughter) However, for those of you that are even the slightest bit squeamish — even though you may not like to admit it in front of your friends — the lights are down. This is a good time to look at your feet, check your Blackberry, do anything other than look at the screen. (Laughter)What I'm about to show you is a diabetic ulcer. And although — it's good to laugh before we look at this. This is the reality of diabetes. I think a lot of times we hear about diabetics, diabetic ulcers, we just don't connect the ulcer with the eventual treatment, which is amputation, if you can't heal it. So I'm going to put the slide up now. It won't be up for long. This is a diabetic ulcer. It's tragic. The treatment for this is amputation. This is an older lady. She has cancer of the liver as well as diabetes, and has decided to die with what' s left of her body intact.And this lady decided, after a year of attempted treatment of that ulcer, that she would try this new therapy that Steve invented. That's what the wound looked like 11 weeks later. That material contained only natural signals. And that material induced the body to switch back on a healing response that it didn't have before.There's going to be a couple more distressing slides for those of you — I'll let you know when you can look again. This is a horse. The horse is not in pain. If the horse was in pain, I wouldn't show you this slide. The horse just has another nostril that's developed because of a riding accident. Just a few weeks after treatment — in this case, taking that material, turning it into a gel, and packing that area, and then repeating the treatment a few times — and the horse heals up. And if you took an ultrasound of that area, it would look great.Here's a dolphin where the fin's been re-attached. There are now 400,000 patients around the world who have used that material to heal their wounds. Could you regenerate a limb? DARPA just gave Steve 15 million dollars to lead an eight-institution project to begin the process of asking that question.And I'll show you the 15 million dollar picture. This is a 78 year-old man who's lost the end of his fingertip. Remember that I mentioned before the children who lose their fingertips. After treatment that's what it looks like. This is happening today. This is clinically relevant today. There are materials that do this. Here are the heart patches.But could you go a little further? Could you, say, instead of using material, can I take some cells along with the material, and remove a damaged piece of tissue, put a bio-degradable material on there? You can see here a little bit of heart muscle beating in a dish. This was done by Teruo Okano at Tokyo Women's Hospital. He can actually grow beating tissue in a dish. He chills the dish, it changes its properties and he peels it right out of the dish. It's the coolest stuff.Now I'm going to show you cell-based regeneration. And what I'm going to show you here is stem cells being removed from the hip of a patient. Again, if you're squeamish, you don't want to watch. But this one's kind of cool. So this is a bypass operation, just like what Al Gore had, with a difference. In this case, at the end of the bypass operation, you're going to see the stem cells from the patient that were removed at the beginning of the procedure being injected directly into the heart of the patient. And I'm standing up here because at one point I'm going to show you just how early this technology is. Here go the stem cells, right into the beating heart of the patient. And if you look really carefully, it's going to be right around this point you'll actually see a back-flush. You see the cells coming back out. We need all sorts of new technology, new devices, to get the cells to the right place at the right time.Just a little bit of data, a tiny bit of data. This was a randomized trial. At this time this was an N of 20. Now there's an N of about 100. Basically, if you take an extremely sick patient and you give them a bypass, they get a little bit better. If you give them stem cells as well as their bypass, for these particular patients, they became asymptomatic. These are now two years out. The coolest thing would be is if you could diagnose the disease early, and prevent the onset of the disease to a bad state.This is the same procedure, but now done minimally invasively, with only three holes in the body where they're taking the heart and simply injecting stem cells through a laparoscopic procedure. There go the cells. We don't have time to go into all of those details, but basically, that works too. You can take patients who are less sick, and bring them back to an almost asymptomatic state through that kind of therapy.Here's another example of stem-cell therapy that isn't quite clinical yet, but I think very soon will be. This is the work of Kacey Marra from Pittsburgh, along with a number of colleagues around the world. They've decided that liposuction fluid, which — in the United States, we have a lot of liposuction fluid. (Laughter) It's a great source of stem cells. Stem cells are packed in that liposuction fluid. So you could go in, you could get your tummy-tuck. Out comes the liposuction fluid, and in this case, the stem cells are isolated and turned into neurons. All done in the lab. And I think fairly soon, you will see patients being treated with their own fat-derived, or adipose-derived, stem cells.I talked before about the use of devices to dramatically change the way we treat disease. Here's just one example before I close up. This is equally tragic. We have a very abiding and heartbreaking partnership with our colleagues at the Institute for Surgical Research in the US Army, who have to treat the now 11,000 kids that have come back from Iraq. Many of those patients are very severely burned.And if there's anything that's been learned about burn, it's that we don't know how to treat it. Everything that is done to treat burn — basically we do a sodding approach. We make something over here, and then we transplant it onto the site of the wound, and we try and get the two to take. In this case here, a new, wearable bio-reactor has been designed — it should be tested clinically later this year at ISR — by Joerg Gerlach in Pittsburgh. And that bio-reactor will lay down in the wound bed. The gun that you see there sprays cells. That's going to spray cells over that area. The reactor will serve to fertilize the environment, deliver other things as well at the same time, and therefore we will seed that lawn, as opposed to try the sodding approach. It's a completely different way of doing it.So my 18 minutes is up. So let me finish up with some good news, and maybe a little bit of bad news. The good news is that this is happening today. It's very powerful work. Clearly the images kind of get that across. It's incredibly difficult because it's highly inter-disciplinary. Almost every field of science engineering and clinical practice is involved in trying to get this to happen.A number of governments, and a number of regions, have recognized that this is a new way to treat disease. The Japanese government were perhaps the first, when they decided to invest first 3 billion, later another 2 billion in this field. It's no coincidence. Japan is the oldest country on earth in terms of its average age. They need this to work or their health system dies. So they're putting a lot of strategic investment focused in this area. The European Union, same thing. China, the same thing. China just launched a national tissue-engineering center. The first year budget was 250 million US dollars.In the United States we've had a somewhat different approach. (Laughter) Oh, for Al Gore to come and be in the real world as president. We've had a different approach. And the approach has basically been to just sort of fund things as they come along. But there's been no strategic investment to bring all of the necessary things to bear and focus them in a careful way.And I'm going to finish up with a quote, maybe a little cheap shot, at the director of the NIH, who's a very charming man. Myself and Jay Vacanti from Harvard went to visit with him and a number of his directors of his institute just a few months ago, to try and convince him that it was time to take just a little piece of that 27.5 billion dollars that he's going to get next year and focus it, in a strategic way, to make sure we can accelerate the pace at which these things get to patients. And at the end of a very testy meeting, what the NIH director said was, "Your vision is larger than our appetite." I'd like to close by saying that no one's going to change our vision, but together we can change his appetite. Thank you.

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I'm going to talk to you today about

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
hopefully converting fear into hope.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:20.958
When we go to the physician today --

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:22.958
when we go to the doctor's office and we walk in,

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:25.958
there are words that we just don't want to hear.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
There are words that we're truly afraid of.

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:31.958
Diabetes, cancer, Parkinson's, Alzheimer's,

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
heart failure, lung failure --

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:36.958
things that we know are debilitating diseases,

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:41.958
for which there's relatively little that can be done.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
And what I want to lay out for you today is

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:47.958
a different way of thinking about how to treat debilitating disease,

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
why it's important,

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
why without it perhaps our health care system will melt down

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
if you think it already hasn't,

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:57.958
and where we are clinically today, and where we might go tomorrow,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
and what some of the hurdles are.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
And we're going to do all of that in 18 minutes, I promise.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
I want to start with this slide,

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:09.958
because this slide sort of tells the story the way Science Magazine thinks of it.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
This was an issue from 2002

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:15.958
that they published with a lot of different articles on the bionic human.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
It was basically a regenerative medicine issue.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:22.958
Regenerative medicine is an extraordinarily simple concept

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
that everybody can understand.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:28.958
It's simply accelerating the pace at which the body heals itself

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.958
to a clinically relevant timescale.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:35.958
So we know how to do this in many of the ways that are up there.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:39.958
We know that if we have a damaged hip, you can put an artificial hip in.

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
And this is the idea that Science Magazine used on their front cover.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:47.958
This is the complete antithesis of regenerative medicine.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
This is not regenerative medicine.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
Regenerative medicine is what Business Week put up

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
when they did a story about regenerative medicine not too long ago.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:02:00.958
The idea is that instead of figuring out how to ameliorate symptoms

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
with devices and drugs and the like --

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
and I'll come back to that theme a few times --

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:09.958
instead of doing that, we will regenerate lost function of the body

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:13.958
by regenerating the function of organs and damaged tissue.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
So that at the end of the treatment,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
you are the same as you were at the beginning of the treatment.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
Very few good ideas -- if you agree that this is a good idea --

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:26.958
very few good ideas are truly novel.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
And this is just the same.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
If you look back in history,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:34.958
Charles Lindbergh, who was better known for flying airplanes,

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:35.958
was actually one of the first people

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:39.958
along with Alexis Carrel, one of the Nobel Laureates from Rockefeller,

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:43.958
to begin to think about, could you culture organs?

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:45.958
And they published this book in 1937,

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
where they actually began to think about,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:52.958
what could you do in bio-reactors to grow whole organs?

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:54.958
We've come a long way since then.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:57.958
I'm going to share with you some of the exciting work that's going on.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
But before doing that, what I'd like to do

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
is share my depression about the health care system

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
and the need for this with you.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
Many of the talks yesterday talked about

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
improving the quality of life, and reducing poverty,

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:14.958
and essentially increasing life expectancy all around the globe.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:19.958
One of the challenges is that the richer we are, the longer we live.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
And the longer we live, the more expensive it is

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
to take care of our diseases as we get older.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
This is simply the wealth of a country

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:32.958
versus the percent of population over the age of 65.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
And you can basically see that the richer a country is,

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
the older the people are within it.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
Why is this important?

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
And why is this a particularly dramatic challenge right now?

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
If the average age of your population is 30,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:49.958
then the average kind of disease that you have to treat

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
is maybe a broken ankle every now and again,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:52.958
maybe a little bit of asthma.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:56.958
If the average age in your country is 45 to 55,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
now the average person is looking at diabetes,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
early-onset diabetes, heart failure, coronary artery disease --

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
things that are inherently more difficult to treat,

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
and much more expensive to treat.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
Just have a look at the demographics in the U.S. here.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
This is from "The Untied States of America."

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:16.958
In 1930, there were 41 workers per retiree.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:21.958
41 people who were basically outside of being really sick,

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:27.958
paying for the one retiree who was experiencing debilitating disease.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
In 2010, two workers per retiree in the U.S.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:35.958
And this is matched in every industrialized, wealthy country in the world.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
How can you actually afford to treat patients

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
when the reality of getting old looks like this?

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
This is age versus cost of health care.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:51.958
And you can see that right around age 45, 40 to 45,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:55.958
there's a sudden spike in the cost of health care.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
It's actually quite interesting. If you do the right studies,

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:03.958
you can look at how much you as an individual spend on your own health care,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
plotted over your lifetime.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
And about seven years before you're about to die, there's a spike.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:10.958
And you can actually --

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
(Laughter)

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:13.958
-- we won't get into that.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:17.958
(Laughter)

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:22.958
There are very few things, very few things that you can really do

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:27.958
that will change the way that you can treat these kinds of diseases

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:31.958
and experience what I would call healthy aging.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
I'd suggest there are four things,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:37.958
and none of these things include an insurance system or a legal system.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
All those things do is change who pays.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
They don't actually change what the actual cost of the treatment is.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
One thing you can do is not treat. You can ration health care.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
We won't talk about that anymore. It's too depressing.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:51.958
You can prevent.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
Obviously a lot of monies should be put into prevention.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
But perhaps most interesting, to me anyway, and most important,

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:03.958
is the idea of diagnosing a disease much earlier on in the progression,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
and then treating the disease to cure the disease

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
instead of treating a symptom.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
Think of it in terms of diabetes, for instance.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
Today, with diabetes, what do we do?

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
We diagnose the disease eventually, once it becomes symptomatic,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.958
and then we treat the symptom for 10, 20, 30, 40 years.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:25.958
And we do OK. Insulin's a pretty good therapy.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:26.958
But eventually it stops working,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:33.958
and diabetes leads to a predictable onset of debilitating disease.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
Why couldn't we just inject the pancreas with something

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
to regenerate the pancreas early on in the disease,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
perhaps even before it was symptomatic?

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
And it might be a little bit expensive at the time that we did it,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
but if it worked, we would truly be able to do something different.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:55.958
This video, I think, gets across the concept that I'm talking about quite dramatically.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
This is a newt re-growing its limb.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
If a newt can do this kind of thing, why can't we?

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
I'll actually show you some more important features

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
But what we're talking about in regenerative medicine

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
