00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
to lift its people out of poverty.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
That's what makes a lot of Africans very angry.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:29.958
And in a way, Africa is more than a tragedy, in more ways than one.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:34.958
There's another enduring tragedy, and that tragedy is that

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
there are so many people, so many governments,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:41.958
so many organizations who want to help the people in Africa.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
They don't understand.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
Now, we're not saying don't help Africa.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.958
Helping Africa is noble.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:56.958
But helping Africa has been turned into a theater of the absurd.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:03:00.958
It's like the blind leading the clueless.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
(Laughter)

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
There are certain things that we need to recognize.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.958
Africa's begging-bowl leaks.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
Did you know that 40 percent of the wealth created in Africa

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
is not invested here in Africa?

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
It's taken out of Africa.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
That's what the World Bank says.

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
Look at Africa's begging-bowl.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
It leaks horribly.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
There are people who think that we should pour more money,

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:35.958
more aid into this bowl which leaks.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
What are the leakages?

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:44.958
Corruption alone costs Africa 148 billion dollars a year.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
Yes, put that aside.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:53.958
Capital flight out of Africa, 80 billion a year.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
Put that aside.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
Let's take food imports.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:04.958
Every year Africa spends 20 billion dollars to import food.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
Just add that up, all these leakages.

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:13.958
That's far more than the 50 billion Tony Blair wants to raise for Africa.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
Now, back in the 1960s Africa not only fed itself,

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
it also exported food.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
Not anymore.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
We know that something has gone fundamentally wrong.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
You know it, I know it, but let's not waste our time

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:34.958
talking about these mistakes because we'll spend all day here.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:40.958
Let's move on, and flip over to the next chapter,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:44.958
and that's what this conference is all about -- the next chapter.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:49.958
The next chapter begins with first of all, asking ourselves

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
this fundamental question,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:55.958
"Whom do we want to help in Africa?"

00:04:56.958 --> 00:05:01.958
There is the people, and then there is the government or leaders.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:09.958
Now, the previous speaker before me,

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:13.958
Idris Mohammed, indicated that

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:18.958
we've had abysmal leadership in Africa.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:23.958
That characterization, in my view, is even more charitable.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
(Laughter)

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
I belong to an Internet discussion forum,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
an African Internet discussion forum,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:41.958
and I asked them, I said, "Since 1960, we've had exactly

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:45.958
204 African heads of state, since 1960."

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:49.958
And I asked them to name me just 20 good leaders,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
just 20 good leaders --

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:57.958
you may want to take this leadership challenge yourself.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
I asked them to name me just 20.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
Everybody mentioned Nelson Mandela, of course.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:09.958
Kwame Nkrumah, Nyerere, Kenyatta -- somebody mentioned Idi Amin.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
(Laughter)

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
I let that pass.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
(Laughter)

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:22.958
My point is, they couldn't go beyond 15.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
Even if they had been able to name me 20,

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
what does that tell you?

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:36.958
20 out of 204 means that the vast majority

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
of the African leaders failed their people.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:46.958
And if you look at them, the slate of the post-colonial leaders --

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:51.958
an assortment of military fufu heads,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:56.958
Swiss-bank socialists, crocodile liberators, vampire elites,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:57.958
quack revolutionaries.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:01.958
(Applause)

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
Now, this leadership is a far cry from the traditional leaders

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
that Africans have known for centuries.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
The second false premise that we make

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:12.958
when we're trying to help Africa

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:18.958
is that sometimes we think that there is something called

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:23.958
a government in Africa that cares about its people,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
serves the interests of the people, and represents the people.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:35.958
There is one particular quote -- a Lesotho chief once said

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
that "Here in Lesotho, we've got two problems:

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
rats and the government."

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
(Laughter)

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
What you and I understand as a government

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
doesn't exist in many African countries.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:54.958
In fact, what we call our governments are vampire states.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
Vampires because they suck

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
the economic vitality out of their people.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
Government is the problem in Africa.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
A vampire state is the government --

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:09.958
(Applause)

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:13.958
-- which has been hijacked by a phalanx of bandits and crooks

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
who use the instruments of state power to enrich themselves,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
their cronies, and tribesmen and exclude everybody else.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:25.958
The richest people in Africa are heads-of-state and ministers,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.958
and quite often the chief bandit is the head-of-state himself.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
Where do they get their money?

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
By creating wealth?

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:36.958
No.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
By raking it off the backs of their suffering people.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
That's not wealth creation. It's wealth redistribution.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:51.958
The third fundamental issue that we have to recognize

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:56.958
is that if we want to help the African people,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
we must know where the African people are.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
Take any African economy.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
An African economy can be broken up into three sectors.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:10.958
There is the modern sector, there is the informal sector

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
and the traditional sector.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
The modern sector is the abode of the elites.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
It's the seat of government.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
In many African countries the modern sector is lost.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
It's dysfunctional.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:31.958
It is a meretricious fandango of imported systems,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
which the elites themselves don't understand.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:39.958
That is the source of many of Africa's problems

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:43.958
where the struggles for political power emanate

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:48.958
and then spill over onto the informal and the traditional sector,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
claiming innocent lives.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
Now the modern sector, of course,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:59.958
is where a lot of the development aid and resources went into.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
More than 80 percent of Ivory Coast's development

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
went into the modern sector.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:11.958
The other sectors, the informal and the traditional sectors,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:15.958
are where you find the majority of the African people,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
the real people in Africa. That's where you find them.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
Now, obviously it makes common sense

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
that if you want to help the people, you go where the people are.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
But that's not what we did.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
As a matter of fact,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:34.958
we neglected the informal and the traditional sectors.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
Now, traditional sector is where Africa produces its agriculture,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
which is one of the reasons why Africa can't feed itself,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
and that's why it must import food.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:49.958
All right, you cannot develop Africa by ignoring

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
the informal and the traditional sectors.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:59.958
And you can't develop the informal and the traditional sectors

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:03.958
without an operational understanding of how these two sectors work.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
These two sectors, let me describe to you,

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
have their own indigenous institutions.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
First one is the political system.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
Traditionally, Africans hate governments. They hate tyranny.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
If you look into their traditional systems,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:25.958
Africans organize their states in two types.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:30.958
The first one belongs to those ethnic societies

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
who believe that the state was necessarily tyrannous,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
so they didn't want to have anything to do

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
with any centralized authority.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
These societies are the Ibo, the Somali, the Kikuyus,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
for example. They have no chiefs.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:52.958
The other ethnic groups, which did have chiefs,

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:56.958
made sure that they surrounded the chiefs

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
with councils upon councils upon councils

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
to prevent them from abusing their power.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
In Ashanti tradition, for example,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
the chief cannot make any decision

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
without the concurrence of the council of elders.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
Without the council the chief can't pass any law,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
and if the chief doesn't govern according to the will of the people

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
he will be removed.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:24.958
If not, the people will abandon the chief,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
go somewhere else and set up a new settlement.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:30.958
And even if you look in ancient African empires,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:35.958
they were all organized around one particular principle --

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
the confederacy principle,

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:41.958
which is characterized by a great deal of devolution of authority,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
decentralization of power.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
Now, this is what I have described to you.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
This is part of Africa's indigenous political heritage.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Now, compare that to the modern systems

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
the ruling elites established on Africa.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
It is a total far cry.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:04.958
In the economic system in traditional Africa,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
the means of production is privately owned.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
It's owned by extended families.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
You see, in the West, the basic economic and social unit

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
is the individual.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
The American will say, "I am because I am,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
and I can damn well do anything I want, anytime."

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
The accent is on the "I."

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:27.958
In Africa, the Africans say, "I am, because we are."

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:31.958
The "we" connotes community -- the extended family system.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
The extended family system pools its resources together.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:38.958
They own farms. They decide what to do, what to produce.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
They don't take any orders from their chiefs.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
They decide what to do.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:47.958
And when they produce their crops, they sell the surplus

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
on marketplaces.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
When they make a profit it is theirs to keep,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
not for the chief to sequester it from them.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:58.958
So, in a nutshell, what we had in traditional Africa

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
was a free-market system.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
There were markets in Africa

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
before the colonialists stepped foot on the continent.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
Timbuktu was one great big market town.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
Kano, Salaga -- they were all there.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:12.958
Even if you go to West Africa, you notice that market activity

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
in West Africa has always been dominated by women.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
So, it's quite appropriate that this section is called

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:19.958
a marketplace.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
The market is not alien to Africa.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:26.958
What Africans practiced was a different form of capitalism,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
but then after independence, all of a sudden,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:33.958
markets, capitalism became a western institution,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:38.958
and the leaders said Africans were ready for socialism.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:39.958
Nonsense.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
And even then, what kind of socialism did they practice?

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
The socialism that they practiced was a peculiar form of

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
Swiss-bank socialism,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
which allowed the heads of states and the ministers

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
to rape and plunder Africa's

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
treasuries for deposit in Switzerland.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:00.958
That is not the kind of system Africans had known for centuries.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:01.958
What do we do now?

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
Go back to Africa's indigenous institutions,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:09.958
and this is where we charge the Cheetahs to go into the informal sectors,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:10.958
the traditional sectors.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
That's where you find the African people.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
And I'd like to show you a quick little video

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
about the informal sector, about the boat-building

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:23.958
that I, myself, tried to mobilize Africans in the Diaspora

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:24.958
to invest in.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
Could you please show that?

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
The men are going fishing in these small boats.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
Yes, it's an enterprise.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:04.958
This is by a local Ghanaian entrepreneur, using his own capital.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
He's getting no assistance from the government,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
and he's building a second, bigger boat.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:13.958
A bigger boat will mean more fish will be caught and landed.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
It means that he will be able to employ more Ghanaians.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.958
It also means that he will be able to generate wealth.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:25.958
And then it will have what economists call

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
external effects on a local economy.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
All that you need to do, all that the elites need to do,

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
is to move this operation into something that is enclosed

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
so that the operation can be made more efficient.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
Now, it is not just this informal sector.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:44.958
There is also traditional medicine.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
80 percent of Africans still rely on traditional medicine.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:51.958
The modern healthcare sector has totally collapsed.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:58.958
Now, this is an area -- I mean, there is a treasure trove of wealth

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
in the traditional medicine area.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.958
This is where we need to mobilize Africans,

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
in the Diaspora especially, to invest in this.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
We also need to mobilize Africans in the Diaspora,

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
not only to go into the traditional sectors,

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:18.958
but to go into agriculture and also to instigate change from within.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:22.958
We were able to mobilize Ghanaians in the Diaspora

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:27.958
to instigate change in Ghana and bring about democracy in Ghana.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:32.958
And I know that with the Cheetahs, we can take Africa back

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.958
one village at a time.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:35.958
Thank you very much.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:43.958
(Applause)

title: Aid versus trade
transcript: It's very, very difficult to speak at the end of a conference like this, because everyone has spoken. Everything has been said. So I thought that what may be useful is to remind us of some of the things that have gone on here, and then maybe offer some ideas which we can take away, and take forward and work on. That's what I'd like to try and do. We came here saying we want to talk about "Africa: the Next Chapter." But we are talking about "Africa: the Next Chapter" because we are looking at the old and the present chapter — that we're looking at, and saying it's not such a good thing. The picture I showed you before, and this picture, of drought, death and disease is what we usually see. What we want to look at is "Africa: the Next Chapter," and that's this: a healthy, smiling, beautiful African. And I think it's worth remembering what we've heard through the conference right from the first day, where I heard that all the important statistics have been given — about where we are now, about how the continent is doing much better. And the importance of that is that we have a platform to build on.So I'm not going to spend too much time — just to show you, refresh your memories that we are here for "Africa: the Next Chapter" because for the first time there really is a platform to build on. We really do have it going right that the continent is growing at rates that people had thought would not happen. After decades of 2 percent, we are now at 5 percent, and it's going to — projected — 6 and 7 percent even. And inflation has come down. External debt — something that I can tell you a long story about because I personally worked on one of the biggest debts on the continent — has come down dramatically. You know, as you can see, from almost 50 billion down to about 12 or 13 billion. Now this is a huge achievement.You know, we've built up reserves. Why is that important? It's because it shows off our economies, shows off our currencies and gives a platform on which people can plan and build, including businesses. We've also seen some evidence that all this is making a difference because private investment flows have increased. I want to remind you again — I know you saw these statistics before — from almost 6 billion we are now at about 18 billion. In 2005, remittances — I just took one country, Nigeria skyrocketing — skyrocketing is too dramatic, but increasing dramatically. And in many other countries this is happening. Why is this important? Because it shows confidence. People are now confident to bring — if your people in the diaspora bring their money back, it shows other people that, look, there is emerging confidence in your country. And instead of an outflow, you are now getting a net inflow.Now, why is all this important, to have to go really fast? It's important that we build this platform, that we have the president, Kikwete, and others of our leaders who are saying, "Look, we must do something different." Because we are confronted with a challenge. 62 percent of our population is below the age of 24. What does this mean? This means that we have to focus on how our youth are going to be engaged in productive endeavor in their lives. You have to focus on how to create jobs, make sure they don't fall into disease, and that they get an education. But most of all that they are productively engaged in life, and that they are creating the kind of productive environment in our countries that will make things happen. And to support this, I just recently — one of the things I've done since leaving government is to start an opinion research organization in Nigeria. Most of our countries don't even have any opinion research. People don't have voice. There is no way you can know what people want.One of the things we asked them recently was what's their top issue. Like in every other country where this has been done, jobs is the top issue. I want to leave this up here and come back to it. But before I get to this slide, I just wanted to run you through this. And to say that for me, the next stage of building this platform that now enables us to move forward — and we mustn't make light of it. It was only 5, 6, 7 years ago we couldn't even talk about the next chapter, because we were in the old chapter. We were going nowhere. The economies were not growing. We were having negative per capita growth. The microeconomic framework and foundation for moving forward was not even there. So let's not forget that it's taken a lot to build this, including all those things that we tried to do in Nigeria that Dele referred to. Creating our own program to solve problems, like fighting corruption, building institutions, stabilizing the micro economy.So now we have this platform we can build on. And it brings us to the debate that has been going on here: aid versus private sector, aid versus trade, etc. And someone stood up to say that one of the frustrating things is that it's been a simplistic debate. And that's not what the debate should be about. That's engaging in the wrong debate. The issue here is how do we get a partnership that involves government donors, the private sector and ordinary African people taking charge of their own lives? How do we combine all this? To move our continent forward, to do the things that need doing that I talked about — getting young people employed. Getting the creative juices flowing on this continent, much of what you have seen here. So I'm afraid we've been engaging a little bit in the wrong debate. We need to bring it back to say, what is the combination of all these factors that is going to yield what we want? (Applause)And I want to tell you something. For me, the issue about aid — I don't think that Africans need to now go all the way over to the other side and feel bad about aid. Africa has been giving the other countries aid. Mo Ibrahim said at a debate we were at that he dreams one day when Africa will be giving aid. And I said, "Mo, you're right. We have — no, but we've already been doing it! The U.K. and the U.S. could not have been built today without Africa's aid."(Applause)It is all the resources that were taken from Africa, including human, that built these countries today! So when they try to give back, we shouldn't be on the defensive. The issue is not that. The issue is how are we using what has been given back. How are we using it? Is it being directed effectively? I want to tell you a little story. Why I don't mind if we get aid, but we use it well. From 1967 to '70, Nigeria fought a war — the Nigeria-Biafra war. And in the middle of that war, I was 14 years old. We spent much of our time with my mother cooking. For the army — my father joined the army as a brigadier — the Biafran army. We were on the Biafran side. And we were down to eating one meal a day, running from place to place, but wherever we could help we did. At a certain point in time, in 1969, things were really bad. We were down to almost nothing in terms of a meal a day. People, children were dying of kwashiorkor. I'm sure some of you who are not so young will remember those pictures. Well, I was in the middle of it.In the midst of all this, my mother fell ill with a stomach ailment for two or three days. We thought she was going to die. My father was not there. He was in the army. So I was the oldest person in the house. My sister fell very ill with malaria. She was three years old and I was 15. And she had such a high fever. We tried everything. It didn't look like it was going to work. Until we heard that 10 kilometers away there was a doctor, who was looking at people and giving them meds. Now I put my sister on my back — burning — and I walked 10 kilometers with her strapped on my back. It was really hot. I was very hungry. I was scared because I knew her life depended on my getting to this woman. We heard there was a woman doctor who was treating people. I walked 10 kilometers, putting one foot in front of the other. I got there and I saw huge crowds. Almost a thousand people were there, trying to break down the door. She was doing this in a church. How was I going to get in?I had to crawl in between the legs of these people with my sister strapped on my back, find a way to a window. And while they were trying to break down the door, I climbed in through the window, and jumped in. This woman told me it was in the nick of time. By the time we jumped into that hall, she was barely moving. She gave a shot of her chloroquine — what I learned was the chloroquine then — gave her some — it must have been a re-hydration — and some other therapies, and put us in a corner. In about two to three hours, she started to move. And then they toweled her down because she started sweating, which was a good sign. And then my sister woke up. And about five or six hours later, she said we could go home. I strapped her on my back. I walked the 10 kilometers back and it was the shortest walk I ever had. I was so happy — (Applause) — that my sister was alive! Today she's 41 years old, a mother of three, and she's a physician saving other lives.Why am I telling that? I'm telling you that because — when it is you or your person involved — you don't care where — whether it's aid. You don't care what it is! (Applause) You just want the person to be alive! And now let me become less sentimental, and say that saving lives — which some of the aid we get does on this continent — when you save the life of anyone, a farmer, a teacher, a mother, they are contributing productively into the economy. And as an economist, we can also look at that side of the story. These are people who are productive agents in the economy. So if we save people from HIV/AIDS, if we save them from malaria, it means they can form the base of production for our economy. And by the same token — as someone said yesterday — if we don't and they die, their children will become a burden on the economy. So even from an economic standpoint, if we leave the social and the humanitarian, we need to save lives now. So that's one of the reasons, from a personal experience, that I say let's channel these resources we get into something productive. However, I will also tell you that I'm one of those who doesn't believe that this is the sole answer. That's why I said the debate has to get more sophisticated. You know, we have to use it well.What has happened in Europe? Do you all know that Spain — part of the EU — got 10 billion dollars in aid from the rest of the EU? Resources that were transferred to them — and were the Spanish ashamed of this? No! The EU transferred 10 billion. Where did they use it? Have you been to southern Spain lately? There are roads everywhere. Infrastructure everywhere. It is on the back of this that the whole of southern Spain has developed into a services economy. Did you know that Ireland got 3 billion dollars in aid? Ireland is one of the fastest-growing economies in the European Union today. For which many people, even from other parts of the world, are going there to find jobs. What did they do with the 3 billion dollars in aid? They used it to build an information superhighway, gain infrastructure that enables them to participate in the information technology revolution, and to create jobs in their economy. They didn't say, "No, you know, we're not going to take this." Today, the European Union is busy transferring aid. My frustration is if they can build infrastructure in Spain — which is roads, highways, other things that they can build — I say then, why do they refuse to use the same aid to build the same infrastructure in our countries? (Applause)When we ask them and tell them what we need, one of my worries today is that we have many foundations now. Now we talk about the World Bank, IMF, and accountability, all that and the EU. We also have private citizens now who have a lot of money — some of them in this audience, with private foundations. And one day, these foundations have so much money, they will overtake the official aid that is being given. But I fear — and I'm very grateful to all of them for what they are trying to do on the continent — but I'm also worried. I wake up with a gnawing in my belly because I see a new set of aid entrepreneurs on the continent. And they're also going from country to country, and many times trying to find what to do. But I'm not really sure that their assistance is also being channeled in the right way. And many of them are not really familiar with the continent. They are just discovering. And many times I don't see Africans working with them. They are just going alone! (Applause)And many times I get the impression that they are not really even interested in hearing from Africans who might know. They want to visit us, see what's happening on the ground and make a decision. And now I'm maybe being harsh. But I worry because this money is so important. Now, who are they accountable to? Are we on their boards when they make decisions about where to channel money? Are we there? Will we make the same mistake that we made before? Have our presidents and our leaders — everyone is talking about — have they ever called these people together and said, "Look, your foundation and your foundation — you have so much money, we are grateful. Let's sit down and really tell you where the money should be channeled and where this aid should go." Have we done that? The answer is no. And each one is making their own individual effort. And then 10 years from now, billions will again have gone into Africa, and we would still have the same problems.This is what gives us the hopeless image. Our inability to take charge and say to all these people bringing their money, "Sit down." And we don't do it because there are so many of us. We don't coordinate. We've not called the Bill Gates, and the Soros, and everybody else who is helping and say, "Sit down. Let's have a conference with you. As a continent, here are our priorities. Here is where we want you to channel this money." Each one should not be an entrepreneur going out and finding what is best. We're not trying to stop them at all! But to help them help us better. And what is disappointing me is that we are not doing this. Ten years from now we will have the same story, and we will be repeating the same things. So our problem right now is, how can we leverage all this good will that is coming towards our way? How can we get government to combine properly with these private foundations, with the international organizations, and with our private sector.I firmly believe in that private sector thing too. But it cannot do it alone. So there might be a few ideas we could think of that could work. They said this is about proliferating and sharing ideas. So why don't we think of using some of this aid? Well, why don't we first say to those helping us out, "Don't be shy about infrastructure. That health that you're working on cannot be sustainable without infrastructure. That education will work better if we've got electricity and railroads, and so on. That agriculture will work better if there are railroads to get the goods to market. Don't be shy of it. Invest some of your resources in that, too." And then we can see that this is one combination of private, international, multilateral money, private sector and the African that we can put together as a partnership, so that aid can be a facilitator. That is all aid can be. Aid cannot solve our problems, I'm firmly convinced about that. But it can be catalytic. And if we fail to use it as catalytic, we would have failed.One of the reasons why China is a bit popular with Africans now — one of the reasons is not only just that, you know, these people are stupid and China is coming to take resources. It's because there's a little more leverage in terms of the Chinese. If you tell them, "We need a road here," they will help you build it. They don't shy away from infrastructure. In fact, the Chinese minister of finance said to me, when I asked him what are we doing wrong in Nigeria. He said, "There are two things you need only. Infrastructure, infrastructure, infrastructure and discipline. You are undisciplined." (Applause) And I repeat it for the continent. It's the same. We need infrastructure, infrastructure and discipline. So we can make a catalytic to help us provide some of that. Now I realize — I'm not saying — health and education — no, you can also provide that as well. But I'm saying it's not either or. Let's see how aid can be a facilitator in partnership. One idea. Second thing, for the private sector, people are afraid to take risks on the continent. Why can't some of this aid be used as a kind of guarantee mechanisms, to enable people to take risk?(Applause)And finally, because they are both standing at my — I'm out of time. Am I out of time? OK, so let me not forget my punchline. One of the things I want everybody to collaborate on is to support women, to create jobs. (Applause) A lot has been said here about women, I don't need to repeat it. But there are people — women — creating jobs. And we know, studies have shown that when you put resources in the hand of the woman — in fact, there's an econometric study, the World Bank Review, done in 2000, showing that transfers into the hands of women result in healthier children, more for the household, more for the economy and all that. So I'm saying that one of the takeaways from here — I'm not saying the men are not important — obviously, if you leave the husbands out, what will they do? They'll come back home and get disgruntled, and it will result in difficulties we don't want. We don't want men beating their wives because they don't have a job, and so on.But at the margin, we also — I want to push this, because the reason is the men automatically — they get — not automatically, but they tend to get more support. But I want you to realize that resources in the hands of African women is a powerful tool. There are people creating jobs. Beatrice Gakuba has created 200 jobs from her flower business in Rwanda. We have Ibukun Awosika in Nigeria, with the chair company. She wants to expand. She needs another 20 million. She will create another 100, 200 more jobs. So take away from here is how are you going to put together the resources to put money in the hands of women in the middle who are ready — business people who want to expand and create more jobs. And lastly, what are you going to do to be part of this partnership of aid, government, private sector and the African as an individual? Thank you. (Applause)

WEBVTT

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:17.958
It's very, very difficult

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:20.958
to speak at the end of a conference like this,

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
because everyone has spoken. Everything has been said.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:26.958
So I thought that what may be useful is to remind us

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
of some of the things that have gone on here,

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:33.958
and then maybe offer some ideas which we can take away,

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:37.958
and take forward and work on.

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:39.958
That's what I'd like to try and do.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:44.958
We came here saying we want to talk about "Africa: the Next Chapter."

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:46.958
But we are talking about "Africa: the Next Chapter"

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:52.958
because we are looking at the old and the present chapter -- that we're looking at,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
and saying it's not such a good thing.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
The picture I showed you before, and this picture, of drought, death and disease

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:02.958
is what we usually see.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
What we want to look at is "Africa: the Next Chapter,"

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:10.958
and that's this: a healthy, smiling, beautiful African.

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:13.958
And I think it's worth remembering what we've heard

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
through the conference right from the first day,

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
where I heard that all the important statistics have been given --

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:21.958
about where we are now,

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
about how the continent is doing much better.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
And the importance of that is that we have a platform to build on.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
So I'm not going to spend too much time --

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
just to show you, refresh your memories

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
that we are here for "Africa: the Next Chapter" because for the first time

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:40.958
there really is a platform to build on.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
We really do have it going right

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:46.958
that the continent is growing at rates that people had thought would not happen.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:50.958
After decades of 2 percent, we are now at 5 percent,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:53.958
and it's going to -- projected -- 6 and 7 percent even.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:57.958
And inflation has come down.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
External debt -- something that I can tell you a long story about

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:04.958
because I personally worked on one of the biggest debts on the continent --

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
has come down dramatically.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
You know, as you can see,

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
from almost 50 billion down to about 12 or 13 billion.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
Now this is a huge achievement.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:19.958
You know, we've built up reserves. Why is that important?

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
It's because it shows off our economies, shows off our currencies

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:27.958
and gives a platform on which people can plan and build, including businesses.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:31.958
We've also seen some evidence that all this is making a difference

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
because private investment flows have increased.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
I want to remind you again --

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
I know you saw these statistics before --

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:41.958
from almost 6 billion we are now at about 18 billion.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
In 2005, remittances -- I just took one country, Nigeria

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:49.958
skyrocketing -- skyrocketing is too dramatic,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
but increasing dramatically.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
And in many other countries this is happening.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
Why is this important? Because it shows confidence.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
People are now confident to bring --

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
if your people in the diaspora bring their money back,

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
it shows other people that, look,

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
there is emerging confidence in your country.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
And instead of an outflow, you are now getting a net inflow.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
Now, why is all this important, to have to go really fast?

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
It's important that we build this platform,

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
that we have the president, Kikwete, and others of our leaders who are saying,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
"Look, we must do something different."

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
Because we are confronted with a challenge.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:30.958
62 percent of our population is below the age of 24.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
What does this mean?

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
This means that we have to focus on how our youth

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
are going to be engaged in productive endeavor in their lives.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
You have to focus on how to create jobs,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
make sure they don't fall into disease, and that they get an education.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
But most of all that they are productively engaged in life,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
and that they are creating the kind of productive environment

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:54.958
in our countries that will make things happen.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
And to support this, I just recently --

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:58.958
one of the things I've done since leaving government

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
is to start an opinion research organization in Nigeria.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
Most of our countries don't even have any opinion research.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
People don't have voice.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
There is no way you can know what people want.

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
One of the things we asked them recently was what's their top issue.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
Like in every other country where this has been done,

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:18.958
jobs is the top issue.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
I want to leave this up here and come back to it.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:27.958
But before I get to this slide, I just wanted to run you through this.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
And to say that for me, the next stage of building this platform

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
that now enables us to move forward --

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
and we mustn't make light of it.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:40.958
It was only 5, 6, 7 years ago

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:44.958
we couldn't even talk about the next chapter, because we were in the old chapter.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
We were going nowhere.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
The economies were not growing.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:53.958
We were having negative per capita growth.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
The microeconomic framework and foundation for moving forward

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
was not even there.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
So let's not forget that it's taken a lot to build this,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
including all those things that we tried to do in Nigeria that Dele referred to.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
Creating our own program to solve problems, like fighting corruption,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:15.958
building institutions, stabilizing the micro economy.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
So now we have this platform we can build on.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
And it brings us to the debate that has been going on here:

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:29.958
aid versus private sector, aid versus trade, etc.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And someone stood up to say that one of the frustrating things

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
is that it's been a simplistic debate.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:41.958
And that's not what the debate should be about.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
That's engaging in the wrong debate.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
The issue here is how do we get a partnership that involves government donors,

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:51.958
the private sector and ordinary African people

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
taking charge of their own lives?

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:59.958
How do we combine all this?

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
To move our continent forward, to do the things that need doing

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
that I talked about -- getting young people employed.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
Getting the creative juices flowing on this continent,

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
much of what you have seen here.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
So I'm afraid we've been engaging a little bit in the wrong debate.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
We need to bring it back to say,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
what is the combination of all these factors

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:22.958
that is going to yield what we want? (Applause)

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:27.958
And I want to tell you something.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
For me, the issue about aid --

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:34.958
I don't think that Africans need to now go all the way over to the other side

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and feel bad about aid.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:38.958
Africa has been giving the other countries aid.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:44.958
Mo Ibrahim said at a debate we were at that

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
he dreams one day when Africa will be giving aid.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
And I said, "Mo, you're right. We have -- no, but we've already been doing it!

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:56.958
The U.K. and the U.S. could not have been built today without Africa's aid."

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:04.958
(Applause)

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
It is all the resources that were taken from Africa,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
including human, that built these countries today!

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:16.958
So when they try to give back, we shouldn't be on the defensive.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
The issue is not that.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
The issue is how are we using what has been given back.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
How are we using it?

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
Is it being directed effectively?

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
I want to tell you a little story.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:44.958
Why I don't mind if we get aid, but we use it well.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
From 1967 to '70, Nigeria fought a war -- the Nigeria-Biafra war.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
And in the middle of that war, I was 14 years old.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
We spent much of our time with my mother cooking.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
For the army -- my father joined the army as a brigadier -- the Biafran army.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
We were on the Biafran side.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
And we were down to eating one meal a day, running from place to place,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
but wherever we could help we did.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:09.958
At a certain point in time, in 1969, things were really bad.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:13.958
We were down to almost nothing in terms of a meal a day.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
People, children were dying of kwashiorkor.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
I'm sure some of you who are not so young

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
will remember those pictures.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
Well, I was in the middle of it.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
In the midst of all this, my mother fell ill with a stomach ailment for two or three days.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
We thought she was going to die.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
My father was not there.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:31.958
He was in the army.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:35.958
So I was the oldest person in the house.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:39.958
My sister fell very ill with malaria.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:45.958
She was three years old and I was 15.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
And she had such a high fever. We tried everything.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
It didn't look like it was going to work.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:55.958
Until we heard that 10 kilometers away there was a doctor, who was

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
looking at people and giving them meds.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
Now I put my sister on my back -- burning --

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
and I walked 10 kilometers with her strapped on my back.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:09.958
It was really hot. I was very hungry.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
I was scared because I knew her life depended on my getting to this woman.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
We heard there was a woman doctor who was treating people.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
I walked 10 kilometers, putting one foot in front of the other.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
I got there and I saw huge crowds.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
Almost a thousand people were there, trying to break down the door.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:28.958
She was doing this in a church. How was I going to get in?

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
I had to crawl in between the legs of these people

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
with my sister strapped on my back,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:37.958
find a way to a window.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
And while they were trying to break down the door,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
I climbed in through the window, and jumped in.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
This woman told me it was in the nick of time.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
By the time we jumped into that hall, she was barely moving.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
She gave a shot of her chloroquine -- what I learned was the chloroquine then --

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
gave her some -- it must have been a re-hydration --

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
and some other therapies, and put us in a corner.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
In about two to three hours, she started to move.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
And then they toweled her down because she started sweating,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:18.958
which was a good sign.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:22.958
And then my sister woke up.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
And about five or six hours later, she said we could go home.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
I strapped her on my back.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
I walked the 10 kilometers back and it was the shortest walk I ever had.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:38.958
I was so happy -- (Applause) -- that my sister was alive!

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
Today she's 41 years old, a mother of three,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
and she's a physician saving other lives.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
Why am I telling that? I'm telling you that because --

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:52.958
when it is you or your person involved --

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
you don't care where -- whether it's aid.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:05.958
You don't care what it is! (Applause)

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:10.958
You just want the person to be alive!

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
And now let me become less sentimental, and say that saving lives --

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
which some of the aid we get does on this continent --

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
when you save the life of anyone, a farmer, a teacher, a mother,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
they are contributing productively into the economy.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:25.958
And as an economist, we can also look at that side of the story.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
These are people who are productive agents in the economy.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:36.958
So if we save people from HIV/AIDS, if we save them from malaria,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
it means they can form the base of production for our economy.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
And by the same token --

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
as someone said yesterday -- if we don't and they die,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
their children will become a burden on the economy.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.958
So even from an economic standpoint,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
if we leave the social and the humanitarian,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
we need to save lives now.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
So that's one of the reasons, from a personal experience, that I say

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:03.958
let's channel these resources we get into something productive.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:09.958
However, I will also tell you that I'm one of those

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
who doesn't believe that this is the sole answer.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
That's why I said the debate has to get more sophisticated.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:20.958
You know, we have to use it well.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:25.958
What has happened in Europe?

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
Do you all know that Spain -- part of the EU --

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:33.958
got 10 billion dollars in aid from the rest of the EU?

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
Resources that were transferred to them --

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
and were the Spanish ashamed of this? No!

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
The EU transferred 10 billion. Where did they use it?

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.958
Have you been to southern Spain lately? There are roads everywhere.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Infrastructure everywhere.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
It is on the back of this that the whole of southern Spain

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
has developed into a services economy.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
Did you know that Ireland got 3 billion dollars in aid?

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:01.958
Ireland is one of the fastest-growing economies in the European Union today.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
For which many people, even from other parts of the world,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
are going there to find jobs.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
What did they do with the 3 billion dollars in aid?

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
They used it to build an information superhighway,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
gain infrastructure that

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:20.958
enables them to participate in the

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
information technology revolution,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
and to create jobs in their economy.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
They didn't say, "No, you know, we're not going to take this."

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
Today, the European Union is busy transferring aid.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
My frustration is if they can build infrastructure in Spain --

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:37.958
which is roads, highways, other things that they can build --

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
I say then, why do they refuse to use the same aid

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
to build the same infrastructure in our countries? (Applause)

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:50.958
When we ask them and tell them what we need,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
one of my worries today is that we have many foundations now.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
Now we talk about the World Bank, IMF, and accountability, all that

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
and the EU.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:04.958
We also have private citizens now who have a lot of money --

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
some of them in this audience, with private foundations.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
And one day, these foundations have so much money,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
they will overtake the official aid that is being given.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
But I fear -- and I'm very grateful to all of them

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
for what they are trying to do on the continent --

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:26.958
but I'm also worried. I wake up with a gnawing in my belly

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
because I see a new set of aid entrepreneurs on the continent.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:33.958
And they're also going from country to country,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:38.958
and many times trying to find what to do.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
But I'm not really sure that their assistance

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:45.958
is also being channeled in the right way.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
And many of them are not really familiar with the continent.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
They are just discovering.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
And many times I don't see Africans working with them.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
They are just going alone! (Applause)

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
And many times I get the impression that they are not really even interested

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:02.958
in hearing from Africans who might know.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
They want to visit us,

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
see what's happening on the ground and make a decision.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
And now I'm maybe being harsh.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
But I worry because this money is so important.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:17.958
Now, who are they accountable to?

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
Are we on their boards when they make decisions

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
about where to channel money? Are we there?

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
Will we make the same mistake that we made before?

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
Have our presidents and our leaders -- everyone is talking about --

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
have they ever called these people together and said,

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
"Look, your foundation and your foundation --

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
you have so much money, we are grateful.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
Let's sit down and really tell you where the money should be channeled

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
and where this aid should go."

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:44.958
Have we done that? The answer is no.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
And each one is making their own individual effort.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
And then 10 years from now, billions will again have gone into Africa,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:55.958
and we would still have the same problems.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
This is what gives us the hopeless image.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:02.958
Our inability to take charge and say to all these people bringing their money,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:03.958
"Sit down."

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
And we don't do it because there are so many of us. We don't coordinate.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:11.958
We've not called the Bill Gates, and the Soros,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:17.958
and everybody else who is helping and say,

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.958
"Sit down. Let's have a conference with you.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
As a continent, here are our priorities.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
Here is where we want you to channel this money."

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
Each one should not be an entrepreneur

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
going out and finding what is best.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:36.958
We're not trying to stop them at all! But to help them help us better.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
And what is disappointing me is that we are not doing this.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
Ten years from now we will have the same story,

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:45.958
and we will be repeating the same things.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:51.958
So our problem right now is, how can we leverage

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:56.958
all this good will that is coming towards our way?

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:01.958
How can we get government to combine properly

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
with these private foundations, with the international organizations,

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
and with our private sector.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
I firmly believe in that private sector thing too.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:12.958
But it cannot do it alone.

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
So there might be a few ideas we could think of that could work.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
They said this is about proliferating and sharing ideas.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:24.958
So why don't we think of using some of this aid?

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
Well, why don't we first say to those helping us out,

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
"Don't be shy about infrastructure.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:33.958
That health that you're working on cannot be sustainable without infrastructure.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:41.958
That education will work better

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:44.958
if we've got electricity and railroads, and so on.

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
That agriculture will work better if there are railroads to get the goods to market.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
Don't be shy of it.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:55.958
Invest some of your resources in that, too."

00:17:55.958 --> 00:18:00.958
And then we can see that this is one combination

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:02.958
of private, international, multilateral money,

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:07.958
private sector and the African that we can put together as a partnership,

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:12.958
so that aid can be a facilitator.

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:15.958
That is all aid can be.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:17.958
Aid cannot solve our problems, I'm firmly convinced about that.

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:21.958
But it can be catalytic. And if we fail to use it as catalytic,

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:25.958
we would have failed.

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
One of the reasons why China is a bit popular with Africans now --

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:34.958
one of the reasons is not only just that, you know, these people are stupid

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:36.958
and China is coming to take resources.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
It's because there's a little more leverage in terms of the Chinese.

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:46.958
If you tell them, "We need a road here,"

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:50.958
they will help you build it.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:51.958
They don't shy away from infrastructure.

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:53.958
In fact, the Chinese minister of finance said to me,

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:55.958
when I asked him what are we doing wrong in Nigeria.

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:58.958
He said, "There are two things you need only.

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:01.958
Infrastructure, infrastructure, infrastructure and discipline.

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:04.958
You are undisciplined." (Applause)

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:13.958
And I repeat it for the continent.

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:15.958
It's the same. We need infrastructure, infrastructure and discipline.

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:18.958
So we can make a catalytic to help us provide some of that.

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:21.958
Now I realize -- I'm not saying -- health and education --

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:25.958
no, you can also provide that as well.

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:28.958
But I'm saying it's not either or.

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:29.958
Let's see how aid can be a facilitator in partnership.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:32.958
One idea.

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:36.958
Second thing, for the private sector,

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:40.958
people are afraid to take risks on the continent.

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:42.958
Why can't some of this aid be used as a kind of guarantee mechanisms,

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:46.958
to enable people to take risk?

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:47.958
(Applause)

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:53.958
And finally, because they are both standing at my -- I'm out of time.

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:56.958
Am I out of time?

00:19:56.958 --> 00:19:59.958
OK, so let me not forget my punchline.

00:19:59.958 --> 00:20:02.958
One of the things I want everybody to collaborate on is

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:11.958
to support women, to create jobs. (Applause)

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:13.958
A lot has been said here about women, I don't need to repeat it.

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:15.958
But there are people -- women -- creating jobs.

00:20:16.958 --> 00:20:18.958
And we know, studies have shown

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:21.958
that when you put resources in the hand of the woman --

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:23.958
in fact, there's an econometric study,

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:26.958
the World Bank Review, done in 2000, showing that

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:29.958
transfers into the hands of women result

00:20:29.958 --> 00:20:32.958
in healthier children, more for the household, more for the economy and all that.

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:36.958
So I'm saying that one of the takeaways from here --

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:38.958
I'm not saying the men are not important --

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:41.958
obviously, if you leave the husbands out, what will they do?

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:43.958
They'll come back home and get disgruntled,

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:46.958
and it will result in difficulties we don't want.

00:20:47.958 --> 00:20:49.958
We don't want men beating their wives

00:20:49.958 --> 00:20:51.958
because they don't have a job, and so on.

00:20:52.958 --> 00:20:55.958
But at the margin, we also -- I want to push this,

00:20:55.958 --> 00:20:58.958
because the reason is the men automatically --

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:02.958
they get -- not automatically, but they tend to get more support.

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:07.958
But I want you to realize that resources

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:11.958
in the hands of African women is a powerful tool.

00:21:11.958 --> 00:21:15.958
There are people creating jobs.

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:17.958
Beatrice Gakuba has created 200 jobs from her flower business in Rwanda.

00:21:17.958 --> 00:21:21.958
We have Ibukun Awosika in Nigeria, with the chair company.

00:21:22.958 --> 00:21:23.958
She wants to expand.

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:26.958
She needs another 20 million.

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:29.958
She will create another 100, 200 more jobs.

00:21:30.958 --> 00:21:34.958
So take away from here is how are you going to put together

00:21:34.958 --> 00:21:36.958
the resources to put money in the hands of women in the middle

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:40.958
who are ready --

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:42.958
business people who want to expand and create more jobs.

00:21:43.958 --> 00:21:47.958
And lastly, what are you going to do

00:21:48.958 --> 00:21:53.958
to be part of this partnership of aid, government, private sector

00:21:53.958 --> 00:21:56.958
and the African as an individual?

00:21:56.958 --> 00:22:05.958
Thank you. (Applause)

title: How I built a windmill

How did you realize that?WK: After I dropped out of school, I went to library, and I read a book that would — "Using Energy," and I get information about doing the mill. And I tried, and I made it.(Applause)CA: So you copied — you exactly copied the design in the book.WK: Ah, no. I just —CA: What happened?WK: In fact, a design of the windmill that was in the book, it has got four — ah — three blades, and mine has got four blades.CA: The book had three, yours had four.WK: Yeah.CA: And you made it out of what?WK: I made four blades, just because I want to increase power.CA: OK.WK: Yeah.CA: You tested three, and found that four worked better?WK: Yeah. The windmill.CA: And so, and that windmill, what — it worked?WK: When the wind blows, it rotates and generates.CA: How much electricity?WK: 12 watts.CA: And so, that lit a light for the house? William Kamkwamba: Thanks.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:27.958

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:29.958

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
CA: OK. Now, you're 19 now?

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
WK: Yeah. I'm 19 years now.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:40.958
CA: Five years ago you had an idea. What was that?

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:43.958
CA: A windmill?

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:44.958
WK: Yeah.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:48.958

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:53.958

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:01.958
and I read a book that would -- "Using Energy,"
