And when you improve searchability,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
you actually take away the one advantage of print, which is serendipity.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
Serendipity is when you find things you weren't looking for,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
because finding what you are looking for is so damned difficult.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:52.958
So -- (Laughter) (Applause) -- now, when you think about this,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
what we have here is a ham butt problem.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
Does everyone know the ham butt problem?

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
Woman's making a ham for a big, family dinner.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
She goes to cut the butt off the ham and throw it away,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:02.958
and she looks at this piece of ham and she's like,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
"This is a perfectly good piece of ham. Why am I throwing this away?"

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
She thought, "Well, my mom always did this."

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:07.958
So she calls up mom, and she says,

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
"Mom, why'd you cut the butt off the ham, when you're making a ham?"

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
She says, "I don't know, my mom always did it!"

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
So they call grandma, and grandma says,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:18.958
"My pan was too small!" (Laughter)

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:22.958
So, it's not that we have good words and bad words.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
We have a pan that's too small!

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
You know, that ham butt is delicious! There's no reason to throw it away.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
The bad words -- see, when people think about a place

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
and they don't find a place on the map,

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
they think, "This map sucks!"

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
When they find a nightspot or a bar, and it's not in the guidebook,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
they're like, "Ooh, this place must be cool! It's not in the guidebook."

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
When they find a word that's not in the dictionary, they think,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:47.958
"This must be a bad word." Why? It's more likely to be a bad dictionary.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:52.958
Why are you blaming the ham for being too big for the pan?

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
So, you can't get a smaller ham.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
The English language is as big as it is.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
So, if you have a ham butt problem,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
and you're thinking about the ham butt problem,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:07.958
the conclusion that it leads you to is inexorable and counterintuitive:

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
paper is the enemy of words.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:14.958
How can this be? I mean, I love books. I really love books.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
Some of my best friends are books.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:21.958
But the book is not the best shape for the dictionary.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
Now they're going to think "Oh, boy.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
People are going to take away my beautiful, paper dictionaries?"

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
No. There will still be paper dictionaries.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.958
When we had cars -- when cars became the dominant mode of transportation,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
we didn't round up all the horses and shoot them.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
You know, there're still going to be paper dictionaries,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
but it's not going to be the dominant dictionary.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
The book-shaped dictionary is not going to be the only shape

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
dictionaries come in. And it's not going to be

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:49.958
the prototype for the shapes dictionaries come in.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:53.958
So, think about it this way: if you've got an artificial constraint,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:57.958
artificial constraints lead to

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:01.958
arbitrary distinctions and a skewed worldview.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
What if biologists could only study animals

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
that made people go, "Aww." Right?

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
What if we made aesthetic judgments about animals,

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:13.958
and only the ones we thought were cute were the ones that we could study?

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:17.958
We'd know a whole lot about charismatic megafauna,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
and not very much about much else.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
And I think this is a problem.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
I think we should study all the words,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:28.958
because when you think about words, you can make beautiful expressions

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:32.958
from very humble parts.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:36.958
Lexicography is really more about material science.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
We are studying the tolerances of the materials

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
that you use to build the structure of your expression:

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:49.958
your speeches and your writing. And then, often people say to me,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:54.958
"Well, OK, how do I know that this word is real?"

00:07:54.958 --> 00:08:01.958
They think, "OK, if we think words are the tools

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
that we use to build the expressions of our thoughts,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
how can you say that screwdrivers are better than hammers?

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
How can you say that a sledgehammer is better than a ball-peen hammer?"

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
They're just the right tools for the job.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
And so people say to me, "How do I know if a word is real?"

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
You know, anybody who's read a children's book

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:22.958
knows that love makes things real.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:27.958
If you love a word, use it. That makes it real.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
Being in the dictionary is an artificial distinction.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
It doesn't make a word any more real than any other way.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
If you love a word, it becomes real.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
So if we're not worrying about directing traffic,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:45.958
if we've transcended paper, if we are worrying less

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:49.958
about control and more about description,

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
then we can think of the English language

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
as being this beautiful mobile.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
And any time one of those little parts of the mobile changes,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
is touched, any time you touch a word,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
you use it in a new context, you give it a new connotation,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
you verb it, you make the mobile move.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:08.958
You didn't break it. It's just in a new position,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
and that new position can be just as beautiful.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:15.958
Now, if you're no longer a traffic cop --

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
the problem with being a traffic cop is

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
there can only be so many traffic cops in any one intersection,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
or the cars get confused. Right?

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
But if your goal is no longer to direct the traffic,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:30.958
but maybe to count the cars that go by, then more eyeballs are better.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
You can ask for help!

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:36.958
If you ask for help, you get more done. And we really need help.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
Library of Congress: 17 million books,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
of which half are in English.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:46.958
If only one out of every 10 of those books

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
had a word that's not in the dictionary in it,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
that would be equivalent to more than two unabridged dictionaries.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
And I find an un-dictionaried word --

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
a word like "un-dictionaried," for example --

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:01.958
in almost every book I read. What about newspapers?

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:06.958
Newspaper archive goes back to 1759,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:11.958
58.1 million newspaper pages. If only one in 100

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
of those pages had an un-dictionaried word on it,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
it would be an entire other OED.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:22.958
That's 500,000 more words. So that's a lot.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
And I'm not even talking about magazines. I'm not talking about blogs --

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
and I find more new words on BoingBoing in a given week

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
than I do Newsweek or Time.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
There's a lot going on there.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
And I'm not even talking about polysemy,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
which is the greedy habit some words have of taking

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:41.958
more than one meaning for themselves.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:45.958
So if you think of the word "set," a set can be a badger's burrow,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
a set can be one of the pleats in an Elizabethan ruff,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
and there's one numbered definition in the OED.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
The OED has 33 different numbered definitions for set.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
Tiny, little word, 33 numbered definitions.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:01.958
One of them is just labeled "miscellaneous technical senses."

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Do you know what that says to me?

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:07.958
That says to me, it was Friday afternoon and somebody wanted to go down the pub. (Laughter)

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
That's a lexicographical cop out,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
to say, "miscellaneous technical senses."

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:15.958
So, we have all these words, and we really need help!

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
And the thing is, we could ask for help --

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:19.958
asking for help's not that hard.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
I mean, lexicography is not rocket science.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
See, I just gave you a lot of words and a lot of numbers,

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
and this is more of a visual explanation.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
If we think of the dictionary as being the map of the English language,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
these bright spots are what we know about,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
and the dark spots are where we are in the dark.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:40.958
If that was the map of all the words in American English, we don't know very much.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
And we don't even know the shape of the language.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
If this was the dictionary -- if this was the map of American English --

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
look, we have a kind of lumpy idea of Florida,

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
but there's no California!

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
We're missing California from American English.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:12:00.958
We just don't know enough, and we don't even know that we're missing California.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
We don't even see that there's a gap on the map.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
So again, lexicography is not rocket science.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
But even if it were, rocket science is being done

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:12.958
by dedicated amateurs these days. You know?

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:16.958
It can't be that hard to find some words!

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:19.958
So, enough scientists in other disciplines

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
are really asking people to help, and they're doing a good job of it.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
For instance, there's eBird, where amateur birdwatchers

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
can upload information about their bird sightings.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
And then, ornithologists can go

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
and help track populations, migrations, etc.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
And there's this guy, Mike Oates. Mike Oates lives in the U.K.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:38.958
He's a director of an electroplating company.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
He's found more than 140 comets.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
He's found so many comets, they named a comet after him.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:45.958
It's kind of out past Mars. It's a hike.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
I don't think he's getting his picture taken there anytime soon.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:51.958
But he found 140 comets without a telescope.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
He downloaded data from the NASA SOHO satellite,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
and that's how he found them.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:00.958
If we can find comets without a telescope,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
shouldn't we be able to find words?

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
Now, y'all know where I'm going with this.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
Because I'm going to the Internet, which is where everybody goes.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
And the Internet is great for collecting words,

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:10.958
because the Internet's full of collectors.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
And this is a little-known technological fact about the Internet,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
but the Internet is actually made up of words and enthusiasm.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:21.958
And words and enthusiasm actually happen to be

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
the recipe for lexicography. Isn't that great?

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
So there are a lot of really good word-collecting sites out there right now,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
but the problem with some of them is that they're not scientific enough.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
They show the word, but they don't show any context.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
Where did it come from? Who said it?

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
What newspaper was it in? What book?

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:41.958
Because a word is like an archaeological artifact.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
If you don't know the provenance or the source of the artifact,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
it's not science, it's a pretty thing to look at.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
So a word without its source is like a cut flower.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:54.958
You know, it's pretty to look at for a while, but then it dies.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:55.958
It dies too fast.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:59.958
So, this whole time I've been saying,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
"The dictionary, the dictionary, the dictionary, the dictionary."

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
Not "a dictionary," or "dictionaries." And that's because,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
well, people use the dictionary to stand for the whole language.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
They use it synecdochically.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
And one of the problems of knowing a word like "synecdochically"

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
is that you really want an excuse to say "synecdochically."

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
This whole talk has just been an excuse to get me to the point

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
where I could say "synecdochically" to all of you.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
So I'm really sorry. But when you use a part of something --

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
like the dictionary is a part of the language,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:30.958
or a flag stands for the United States, it's a symbol of the country --

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.958
then you're using it synecdochically.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:38.958
But the thing is, we could make the dictionary the whole language.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:42.958
If we get a bigger pan, then we can put all the words in.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:46.958
We can put in all the meanings.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:50.958
Doesn't everyone want more meaning in their lives?

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:54.958
And we can make the dictionary not just be a symbol of the language --

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
we can make it be the whole language.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
You see, what I'm really hoping for is that my son,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
who turns seven this month -- I want him to barely remember

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:07.958
that this is the form factor that dictionaries used to come in.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
This is what dictionaries used to look like.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
I want him to think of this kind of dictionary as an eight-track tape.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:15.958
It's a format that died because it wasn't useful enough.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
It wasn't really what people needed.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
And the thing is, if we can put in all the words,

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:25.958
no longer have that artificial distinction between good and bad,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
we can really describe the language like scientists.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
We can leave the aesthetic judgments to the writers and the speakers.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:34.958
If we can do that, then I can spend all my time fishing,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:39.958
and I don't have to be a traffic cop anymore.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
Thank you very much for your kind attention.

title: Aid for Africa? No thanks.
transcript: I am very, very happy to be amidst some of the most — the lights are really disturbing my eyes and they're reflecting on my glasses. I am very happy and honored to be amidst very, very innovative and intelligent people. I have listened to the three previous speakers, and guess what happened? Every single thing I planned to say, they have said it here, and it looks and sounds like I have nothing else to say.(Laughter)But there is a saying in my culture that if a bud leaves a tree without saying something, that bud is a young one. So, I will — since I am not young and am very old, I still will say something.We are hosting this conference at a very opportune moment, because another conference is taking place in Berlin. It is the G8 Summit. The G8 Summit proposes that the solution to Africa's problems should be a massive increase in aid, something akin to the Marshall Plan. Unfortunately, I personally do not believe in the Marshall Plan. One, because the benefits of the Marshall Plan have been overstated. Its largest recipients were Germany and France, and it was only 2.5 percent of their GDP. An average African country receives foreign aid to the tune of 13, 15 percent of its GDP, and that is an unprecedented transfer of financial resources from rich countries to poor countries.But I want to say that there are two things we need to connect. How the media covers Africa in the West, and the consequences of that. By displaying despair, helplessness and hopelessness, the media is telling the truth about Africa, and nothing but the truth. However, the media is not telling us the whole truth. Because despair, civil war, hunger and famine, although they're part and parcel of our African reality, they are not the only reality. And secondly, they are the smallest reality.Africa has 53 nations. We have civil wars only in six countries, which means that the media are covering only six countries. Africa has immense opportunities that never navigate through the web of despair and helplessness that the Western media largely presents to its audience. But the effect of that presentation is, it appeals to sympathy. It appeals to pity. It appeals to something called charity. And, as a consequence, the Western view of Africa's economic dilemma is framed wrongly. The wrong framing is a product of thinking that Africa is a place of despair. What should we do with it? We should give food to the hungry. We should deliver medicines to those who are ill. We should send peacekeeping troops to serve those who are facing a civil war. And in the process, Africa has been stripped of self-initiative.I want to say that it is important to recognize that Africa has fundamental weaknesses. But equally, it has opportunities and a lot of potential. We need to reframe the challenge that is facing Africa, from a challenge of despair, which is called poverty reduction, to a challenge of hope. We frame it as a challenge of hope, and that is worth creation. The challenge facing all those who are interested in Africa is not the challenge of reducing poverty. It should be a challenge of creating wealth.Once we change those two things — if you say the Africans are poor and they need poverty reduction, you have the international cartel of good intentions moving onto the continent, with what? Medicines for the poor, food relief for those who are hungry, and peacekeepers for those who are facing civil war. And in the process, none of these things really are productive because you are treating the symptoms, not the causes of Africa's fundamental problems. Sending somebody to school and giving them medicines, ladies and gentlemen, does not create wealth for them. Wealth is a function of income, and income comes from you finding a profitable trading opportunity or a well-paying job.Now, once we begin to talk about wealth creation in Africa, our second challenge will be, who are the wealth-creating agents in any society? They are entrepreneurs. [Unclear] told us they are always about four percent of the population, but 16 percent are imitators. But they also succeed at the job of entrepreneurship. So, where should we be putting the money? We need to put money where it can productively grow. Support private investment in Africa, both domestic and foreign. Support research institutions, because knowledge is an important part of wealth creation.But what is the international aid community doing with Africa today? They are throwing large sums of money for primary health, for primary education, for food relief. The entire continent has been turned into a place of despair, in need of charity. Ladies and gentlemen, can any one of you tell me a neighbor, a friend, a relative that you know, who became rich by receiving charity? By holding the begging bowl and receiving alms? Does any one of you in the audience have that person? Does any one of you know a country that developed because of the generosity and kindness of another? Well, since I'm not seeing the hand, it appears that what I'm stating is true.(Bono: Yes!)Andrew Mwenda: I can see Bono says he knows the country. Which country is that?(Bono: It's an Irish land.)(Laughter)(Bono: [unclear])AM: Thank you very much. But let me tell you this. External actors can only present to you an opportunity. The ability to utilize that opportunity and turn it into an advantage depends on your internal capacity. Africa has received many opportunities. Many of them we haven't benefited much. Why? Because we lack the internal, institutional framework and policy framework that can make it possible for us to benefit from our external relations. I'll give you an example.Under the Cotonou Agreement, formerly known as the Lome Convention, African countries have been given an opportunity by Europe to export goods, duty-free, to the European Union market. My own country, Uganda, has a quota to export 50,000 metric tons of sugar to the European Union market. We haven't exported one kilogram yet. We import 50,000 metric tons of sugar from Brazil and Cuba. Secondly, under the beef protocol of that agreement, African countries that produce beef have quotas to export beef duty-free to the European Union market. None of those countries, including Africa's most successful nation, Botswana, has ever met its quota.So, I want to argue today that the fundamental source of Africa's inability to engage the rest of the world in a more productive relationship is because it has a poor institutional and policy framework. And all forms of intervention need support, the evolution of the kinds of institutions that create wealth, the kinds of institutions that increase productivity. How do we begin to do that, and why is aid the bad instrument? Aid is the bad instrument, and do you know why? Because all governments across the world need money to survive. Money is needed for a simple thing like keeping law and order. You have to pay the army and the police to show law and order. And because many of our governments are quite dictatorial, they need really to have the army clobber the opposition. The second thing you need to do is pay your political hangers-on. Why should people support their government? Well, because it gives them good, paying jobs, or, in many African countries, unofficial opportunities to profit from corruption.The fact is no government in the world, with the exception of a few, like that of Idi Amin, can seek to depend entirely on force as an instrument of rule. Many countries in the [unclear], they need legitimacy. To get legitimacy, governments often need to deliver things like primary education, primary health, roads, build hospitals and clinics. If the government's fiscal survival depends on it having to raise money from its own people, such a government is driven by self-interest to govern in a more enlightened fashion. It will sit with those who create wealth. Talk to them about the kind of policies and institutions that are necessary for them to expand a scale and scope of business so that it can collect more tax revenues from them. The problem with the African continent and the problem with the aid industry is that it has distorted the structure of incentives facing the governments in Africa. The productive margin in our governments' search for revenue does not lie in the domestic economy, it lies with international donors.Rather than sit with Ugandan —(Applause) —rather than sit with Ugandan entrepreneurs, Ghanaian businessmen, South African enterprising leaders, our governments find it more productive to talk to the IMF and the World Bank. I can tell you, even if you have ten Ph.Ds., you can never beat Bill Gates in understanding the computer industry. Why? Because the knowledge that is required for you to understand the incentives necessary to expand a business — it requires that you listen to the people, the private sector actors in that industry.Governments in Africa have therefore been given an opportunity, by the international community, to avoid building productive arrangements with your own citizens, and therefore allowed to begin endless negotiations with the IMF and the World Bank, and then it is the IMF and the World Bank that tell them what its citizens need. In the process, we, the African people, have been sidelined from the policy-making, policy-orientation, and policy- implementation process in our countries. We have limited input, because he who pays the piper calls the tune. The IMF, the World Bank, and the cartel of good intentions in the world has taken over our rights as citizens, and therefore what our governments are doing, because they depend on aid, is to listen to international creditors rather than their own citizens.But I want to put a caveat on my argument, and that caveat is that it is not true that aid is always destructive. Some aid may have built a hospital, fed a hungry village. It may have built a road, and that road may have served a very good role. The mistake of the international aid industry is to pick these isolated incidents of success, generalize them, pour billions and trillions of dollars into them, and then spread them across the whole world, ignoring the specific and unique circumstances in a given village, the skills, the practices, the norms and habits that allowed that small aid project to succeed — like in Sauri village, in Kenya, where Jeffrey Sachs is working — and therefore generalize this experience as the experience of everybody.Aid increases the resources available to governments, and that makes working in a government the most profitable thing you can have, as a person in Africa seeking a career. By increasing the political attractiveness of the state, especially in our ethnically fragmented societies in Africa, aid tends to accentuate ethnic tensions as every single ethnic group now begins struggling to enter the state in order to get access to the foreign aid pie. Ladies and gentlemen, the most enterprising people in Africa cannot find opportunities to trade and to work in the private sector because the institutional and policy environment is hostile to business. Governments are not changing it. Why? Because they don't need to talk to their own citizens. They talk to international donors. So, the most enterprising Africans end up going to work for government, and that has increased the political tensions in our countries precisely because we depend on aid.I also want to say that it is important for us to note that, over the last 50 years, Africa has been receiving increasing aid from the international community, in the form of technical assistance, and financial aid, and all other forms of aid. Between 1960 and 2003, our continent received 600 billion dollars of aid, and we are still told that there is a lot of poverty in Africa. Where has all the aid gone?I want to use the example of my own country, called Uganda, and the kind of structure of incentives that aid has brought there. In the 2006-2007 budget, expected revenue: 2.5 trillion shillings. The expected foreign aid: 1.9 trillion. Uganda's recurrent expenditure — by recurrent what do I mean? Hand-to-mouth is 2.6 trillion. Why does the government of Uganda budget spend 110 percent of its own revenue? It's because there's somebody there called foreign aid, who contributes for it. But this shows you that the government of Uganda is not committed to spending its own revenue to invest in productive investments, but rather it devotes this revenue to paying structure of public expenditure. Public administration, which is largely patronage, takes 690 billion. The military, 380 billion. Agriculture, which employs 18 percent of our poverty-stricken citizens, takes only 18 billion. Trade and industry takes 43 billion. And let me show you, what does public expenditure — rather, public administration expenditure — in Uganda constitute? There you go. 70 cabinet ministers, 114 presidential advisers, by the way, who never see the president, except on television.(Laughter)(Applause)And when they see him physically, it is at public functions like this, and even there, it is him who advises them.(Laughter)We have 81 units of local government. Each local government is organized like the central government — a bureaucracy, a cabinet, a parliament, and so many jobs for the political hangers-on. There were 56, and when our president wanted to amend the constitution and remove term limits, he had to create 25 new districts, and now there are 81. Three hundred thirty-three members of parliament. You need Wembley Stadium to host our parliament. One hundred thirty-four commissions and semi-autonomous government bodies, all of which have directors and the cars. And the final thing, this is addressed to Mr. Bono. In his work, he may help us on this.A recent government of Uganda study found that there are 3,000 four-wheel drive motor vehicles at the Minister of Health headquarters. Uganda has 961 sub-counties, each of them with a dispensary, none of which has an ambulance. So, the four-wheel drive vehicles at the headquarters drive the ministers, the permanent secretaries, the bureaucrats and the international aid bureaucrats who work in aid projects, while the poor die without ambulances and medicine.Finally, I want to say that before I came to speak here, I was told that the principle of TEDGlobal is that the good speech should be like a miniskirt. It should be short enough to arouse interest, but long enough to cover the subject. I hope I have achieved that.(Laughter)Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:16.958
I am very, very happy to be amidst some of the most --

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
the lights are really disturbing my eyes

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
and they're reflecting on my glasses.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:24.958
I am very happy and honored to be amidst

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:27.958
very, very innovative and intelligent people.

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
I have listened to the three previous speakers,

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
and guess what happened?

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
Every single thing I planned to say, they have said it here,

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:40.958
and it looks and sounds like I have nothing else to say.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:41.958
(Laughter)

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
But there is a saying in my culture

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:49.958
that if a bud leaves a tree without saying something,

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
that bud is a young one.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:57.958
So, I will -- since I am not young and am very old,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
I still will say something.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:04.958
We are hosting this conference at a very opportune moment,

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:06.958
because another conference is taking place in Berlin.

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:09.958
It is the G8 Summit.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:16.958
The G8 Summit proposes that the solution to Africa's problems

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:19.958
should be a massive increase in aid,

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
something akin to the Marshall Plan.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:25.958
Unfortunately, I personally do not believe in the Marshall Plan.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:30.958
One, because the benefits of the Marshall Plan have been overstated.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
Its largest recipients were Germany and France,

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:36.958
and it was only 2.5 percent of their GDP.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
An average African country receives foreign aid

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:45.958
to the tune of 13, 15 percent of its GDP,

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:48.958
and that is an unprecedented transfer of financial resources

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:51.958
from rich countries to poor countries.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
But I want to say that there are two things we need to connect.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:02:00.958
How the media covers Africa in the West, and the consequences of that.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
By displaying despair, helplessness and hopelessness,

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:09.958
the media is telling the truth about Africa, and nothing but the truth.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:13.958
However, the media is not telling us the whole truth.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:17.958
Because despair, civil war, hunger and famine,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:21.958
although they're part and parcel of our African reality,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
they are not the only reality.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
And secondly, they are the smallest reality.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
Africa has 53 nations.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
We have civil wars only in six countries,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:34.958
which means that the media are covering only six countries.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:38.958
Africa has immense opportunities that never navigate

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
through the web of despair and helplessness

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:45.958
that the Western media largely presents to its audience.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:49.958
But the effect of that presentation is, it appeals to sympathy.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:54.958
It appeals to pity. It appeals to something called charity.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:57.958
And, as a consequence, the Western view

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:02.958
of Africa's economic dilemma is framed wrongly.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:06.958
The wrong framing is a product of thinking

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
that Africa is a place of despair.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:12.958
What should we do with it? We should give food to the hungry.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
We should deliver medicines to those who are ill.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
We should send peacekeeping troops

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
to serve those who are facing a civil war.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:24.958
And in the process, Africa has been stripped of self-initiative.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.958
I want to say that it is important to recognize

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
But equally, it has opportunities and a lot of potential.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:38.958

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
from a challenge of despair,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:44.958
which is called poverty reduction,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
to a challenge of hope.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:50.958
We frame it as a challenge of hope, and that is worth creation.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:53.958
The challenge facing all those who are interested in Africa

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
is not the challenge of reducing poverty.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:58.958
It should be a challenge of creating wealth.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
Once we change those two things --

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:06.958
if you say the Africans are poor and they need poverty reduction,

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:10.958
you have the international cartel of good intentions

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
moving onto the continent, with what?

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
Medicines for the poor, food relief for those who are hungry,

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:21.958
and peacekeepers for those who are facing civil war.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:25.958
And in the process, none of these things really are productive

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
because you are treating the symptoms, not the causes

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
of Africa's fundamental problems.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
Sending somebody to school and giving them medicines,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:38.958
ladies and gentlemen, does not create wealth for them.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:42.958
Wealth is a function of income, and income comes from you finding

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:46.958
a profitable trading opportunity or a well-paying job.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
our second challenge will be,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
who are the wealth-creating agents in any society?

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:58.958

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:02.958
about four percent of the population, but 16 percent are imitators.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:07.958

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:15.958

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:19.958

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:26.958

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.958

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958

By increasing the political attractiveness of the state,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:29.958
especially in our ethnically fragmented societies in Africa,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
aid tends to accentuate ethnic tensions

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:38.958
as every single ethnic group now begins struggling to enter the state

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
in order to get access to the foreign aid pie.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:46.958
Ladies and gentlemen, the most enterprising people in Africa

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:51.958
cannot find opportunities to trade and to work in the private sector

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
because the institutional and policy environment is hostile to business.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
Governments are not changing it. Why?

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:01.958
Because they don't need to talk to their own citizens.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
They talk to international donors.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:08.958
So, the most enterprising Africans end up going to work for government,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
and that has increased the political tensions in our countries

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
precisely because we depend on aid.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:18.958
I also want to say that it is important for us to

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
note that, over the last 50 years, Africa has been receiving increasing aid

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
from the international community,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
in the form of technical assistance, and financial aid,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
and all other forms of aid.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:39.958
Between 1960 and 2003, our continent received 600 billion dollars of aid,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
and we are still told that there is a lot of poverty in Africa.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
Where has all the aid gone?

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
I want to use the example of my own country, called Uganda,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:54.958
and the kind of structure of incentives that aid has brought there.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:14:00.958
In the 2006-2007 budget, expected revenue: 2.5 trillion shillings.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
The expected foreign aid: 1.9 trillion.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
Uganda's recurrent expenditure -- by recurrent what do I mean?

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:11.958
Hand-to-mouth is 2.6 trillion.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:16.958
Why does the government of Uganda budget spend 110 percent

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:17.958
of its own revenue?

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:22.958
It's because there's somebody there called foreign aid, who contributes for it.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
But this shows you that the government of Uganda

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:28.958
is not committed to spending its own revenue

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
to invest in productive investments,

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
but rather it devotes this revenue

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:36.958
to paying structure of public expenditure.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:41.958
Public administration, which is largely patronage, takes 690 billion.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
The military, 380 billion.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:48.958
Agriculture, which employs 18 percent of our poverty-stricken citizens,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
takes only 18 billion.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:55.958
Trade and industry takes 43 billion.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:59.958
And let me show you, what does public expenditure --

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:03.958
rather, public administration expenditure -- in Uganda constitute?

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:09.958
There you go. 70 cabinet ministers, 114 presidential advisers,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
by the way, who never see the president, except on television.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
(Laughter)

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:20.958
(Applause)

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:25.958
And when they see him physically, it is at public functions like this,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:29.958
and even there, it is him who advises them.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
(Laughter)

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
We have 81 units of local government.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
Each local government is organized like the central government --

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
a bureaucracy, a cabinet, a parliament,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
and so many jobs for the political hangers-on.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
There were 56, and when our president wanted to

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
amend the constitution and remove term limits,

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:51.958
he had to create 25 new districts, and now there are 81.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
Three hundred thirty-three members of parliament.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:55.958
You need Wembley Stadium to host our parliament.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
One hundred thirty-four commissions

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:02.958
and semi-autonomous government bodies,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:06.958
all of which have directors and the cars. And the final thing,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
this is addressed to Mr. Bono. In his work, he may help us on this.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
A recent government of Uganda study found

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.958
that there are 3,000 four-wheel drive motor vehicles

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
at the Minister of Health headquarters.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:23.958
Uganda has 961 sub-counties, each of them with a dispensary,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
none of which has an ambulance.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
So, the four-wheel drive vehicles at the headquarters

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
drive the ministers, the permanent secretaries, the bureaucrats

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
and the international aid bureaucrats who work in aid projects,

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:40.958
while the poor die without ambulances and medicine.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:44.958
Finally, I want to say that before I came to speak here,

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:48.958
I was told that the principle of TEDGlobal

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
is that the good speech should be like a miniskirt.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
It should be short enough to arouse interest,

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
but long enough to cover the subject.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:56.958
I hope I have achieved that.

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:57.958
(Laughter)

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:58.958
Thank you very much.

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
(Applause)
